metadata.case_name: Appellant Partnership v. Official Liquidators of Vijaya Lakshmi Sugar Mills Ltd.

facts.text: Appellant is a registered partnership carrying on business at Kanpur.
Appellant entered into an agreement in December 1948 with Vijaya Lakshmi Sugar Mills Limited, Doiwala, District Dehra Dun, appointing appellant as sole selling agent of the Mills.
Under the agreement, appellant deposited Rs. 50,000 as security for due performance of the contract, carrying interest at 6 per cent per annum payable by the Mills.
Agreement was for a period of one year.
In November 1949, an order was passed winding up the Mills before the agency period ended.
Consequent on winding-up, appellant made an application in September 1950 praying for refund of security deposit Rs. 50,000 with interest, claiming Mills held it as trustee entitled to priority.
Appellant also claimed Rs. 24,500 commission, but that claim was given up.
Liquidators admitted the agreement and deposit of Rs. 50,000.
Liquidators contended the amount was an ordinary debt, no preference, and appellant's contention of trust was incorrect.
Company Judge held on construction of agreement that amount was ordinary debt, not trust, no preference.
Division Bench of Allahabad High Court upheld Company Judge, dismissed appeal, refused certificate; special leave obtained from Supreme Court.

Key terms of agreement: Clause 8 - Firm deposited Rs. 50,000 as security, Mills to pay 6% interest. Clause 9 - Mills to refund security with interest on termination; if not refunded, entitled to commission as if agency not terminated; agreement remains alive till security with interest and commission paid.
No stipulation in agreement that Rs. 50,000 security would be kept as separate fund; Mills could use it for own purposes while paying interest.

legal_issues.text: Whether the amount of Rs. 50,000 deposited as security for due performance of the contract of sole selling agency was in the nature of a trust entitled to preference or an ordinary debt.

petitioner_arguments.text: The Mills held the amount of deposit as trustee and consequently the appellant was entitled to priority with respect to Rs. 50,000.

respondent_arguments.text: The amount was an ordinary debt with respect to which the appellant could not claim any preference; appellant's contention that the amount deposited was in the nature of a trust was not correct.

court_reasoning.text: On construction of agreement, no stipulation to keep deposit as separate fund; interest payable; nothing preventing Mills from using money as own; Clause 9 puts security deposit and commission on same footing, keeping agreement alive if not refunded.
court_reasoning.key_observation: View of Company Judge correct; deposit ordinary debt.

court_reasoning.text: Apparent conflict between Calcutta/Madras HCs (trust even with interest/use) and Allahabad/Bombay HCs (depends on facts/terms) is illusory; question depends on interpretation of document/facts/circumstances whether trust established.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No leaning towards trust merely because security deposit; consider terms, segregation, interest, conduct.

court_reasoning.text: Principles: If terms clearly indicate trust, holds despite interest; else consider facts like no segregation (against trust per Trust Act s.51), interest (pointer to no trust), other provisions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Here no segregation, Mills could mix/use money, interest paid, security/commission same footing.

court_reasoning.text: Application to case: No segregation; Mills could mix/use deposit; interest provided; ordinary debtor-creditor relationship.

holdings.text: Whether security deposit impressed with trust decided on terms of agreement and facts/circumstances of each case; no automatic trust from mere security deposit.
In this case, deposit is ordinary debt, not trust entitled to preference.

precedents_cited.case_name: Re Alliance Bank of Simla; Peter Donald Macpherson v. Dugald Mckechnie and others
precedents_cited.relevance: Calcutta case: deposit creates trust even with interest/use (provident fund).

precedents_cited.case_name: In the matter of Travancore National and Quilon Bank Limited, Official Liquidators
precedents_cited.relevance: Madras case: security deposit by employee creates trust.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Manekji Petit Manufacturing Company, Limited
precedents_cited.relevance: Bombay: no trust till contingency for segregation; interest, use by company.
Allahabad: interest, use by company, failed floating charge = no trust.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kshetra Mohan Das v. D. C. Basu
precedents_cited.relevance: Calcutta: principle - if impressed with trust/fiduciary, priority; else pro rata creditor.
English: trust inferred from facts/circumstances despite interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Re Halletts Estate, Knatchbull v. Hallett
precedents_cited.relevance: English: fiduciary money mixed still traceable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Frank M. McKey v. Maurcie Paradise

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Added in 1936 amendment for specific provision on employee/provident fund deposits in liquidation.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Trust Act, 1882
statutes_cited.relevance: Trustee cannot use trust property for own profit; absence of segregation against trust.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upholds Allahabad High Court Division Bench and Company Judge; holds security deposit is ordinary debt not entitled to preference as trust; appeal dismissed.

key_quotes.text: the question whether the deposit in a particular case was in the nature of a trust or was an ordinary debt depended on the facts and circumstances of each case.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle resolving apparent conflict between High Courts.

key_quotes.text: The mere fact that money was deposited as a security is not sufficient to come to the conclusion that it must be treated as trust money.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects automatic trust for security deposits.

key_quotes.text: in view of s. 51 of the Indian Trust Act... a trustee cannot use or deal with the trust property for his own profit
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why no segregation points against trust.
